body_html:
Both would be useful - my current use case is for square matrices. This could also be taken from cuSOLVER like cholesky. I don't have time to work on this, but it would involve copying the cholesky op and primarily changing potrf to getrf. Writing a gradient would be the hard bit.
…
Le 27 mai 2017 à 20:35, gilgils ***@***.***> a écrit : Yeah, but from what I remember from Eigen's documentation (perhaps I am wrong), their LU decomposition works only for square matrices. An LU decomposition for rectangular matrices is also very important similar to Scipy and MKL. — You are receiving this because you commented. Both would be useful - my current use case is for square matrices. This could also be taken from cuSOLVER like cholesky.

I don't have time to work on this, but it would involve copying the cholesky op and primarily changing potrf to getrf. Writing a gradient would be the hard bit.

 Le 27 mai 2017 à 20:35, gilgils ***@***.***> a écrit :

 Yeah, but from what I remember from Eigen's documentation (perhaps I am wrong), their LU decomposition works only for square matrices. An LU decomposition for rectangular matrices is also very important similar to Scipy and MKL.

body:
Both would be useful - my current use case is for square matrices. This could also be taken from cuSOLVER like cholesky.

I don't have time to work on this, but it would involve copying the cholesky op and primarily changing potrf to getrf. Writing a gradient would be the hard bit.

> Le 27 mai 2017 à 20:35, gilgils <notifications@github.com> a écrit :
> 
> Yeah, but from what I remember from Eigen's documentation (perhaps I am wrong), their LU decomposition works only for square matrices. An LU decomposition for rectangular matrices is also very important similar to Scipy and MKL.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
